articles.headline: Obama Begins Campaign in Congress for Iran Nuclear Deal
articles.snippet: President Obama is rolling out a public and private campaign to build support for a nuclear deal, and to counter a well-financed onslaught from critics.
articles.abstract: President Obama is rolling out a public and private campaign to build support for a nuclear deal, and to counter a well-financed onslaught from critics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is rolling out a campaign of private entreaties and public advocacy over the next several weeks to build support in Congress for the nuclear deal with Iran, an effort to counter a well-financed onslaught from critics who have promised to use a monthlong congressional recess to pressure lawmakers to oppose the accord.

articles.headline: Up for Sale, The Economist Is Unlikely to Alter Its Voice
articles.snippet: The free-market British newspaper, a 50 percent stake of which is up for sale, has a complex trust system that essentially ensures its journalistic mission.
articles.abstract: The free-market British newspaper, a 50 percent stake of which is up for sale, has a complex trust system that essentially ensures its journalistic mission.
articles.lead_paragraph: Journalists at The Economist speak, half-jokingly, of a mythical, perfect sentence for the news and business weekly. It is some version of this:

articles.headline: An Exchange in Australia Woos Listings From China
articles.snippet: The Asia Pacific Stock Exchange has just two listings now, but its owner, George Wang, has ambitions to to link capital-hungry Chinese companies with Australian investors.
articles.abstract: The Asia Pacific Stock Exchange has just two listings now, but its owner, George Wang, has ambitions to to link capital-hungry Chinese companies with Australian investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Just two companies are listed on the Asia Pacific Stock Exchange in Sydney, and it has to rely on its biggest Australian rival to clear and settle trades.

articles.headline: Puerto Rico Has Another Debt Worry on Horizon
articles.snippet: The government said it stopped making contributions to a fund that would pay an additional $13 billion in bond debt.
articles.abstract: The government said it stopped making contributions to a fund that would pay an additional $13 billion in bond debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: While Puerto Rico’s first bond default in its history reverberated through the financial markets on Tuesday, another move by the cash-poor island may provide a clue to where the next trouble spot lies.

articles.headline: Friends of Joe Biden Worry a Run for President Could Bruise His Legacy
articles.snippet: Few seem eager to tell the vice president of their reservations concerning a possible run for the presidency, regarded as a deeply personal decision.
articles.abstract: Few seem eager to tell the vice president of their reservations concerning a possible run for the presidency, regarded as a deeply personal decision.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Later this month, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will escape for a family retreat to mourn his late son, Beau, but also to mull, as his dying son urged him to do, a campaign for president. Some of Mr. Biden’s friends and allies worry that he will decide it is a good idea.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Jason Horowitz

articles.headline: A Year Later, Ferguson Sees Change, but Asks if It’s Real
articles.snippet: The mostly black town where Michael Brown died is divided between those who think reforms are significant, and those who see them as merely superficial.
articles.abstract: The mostly black town where Michael Brown died is divided between those who think reforms are significant, and those who see them as merely superficial.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Brianna West stepped before the judge as her daughter Morgan, 3, fidgeted beside her. Ms. West had waited weeks to get this case behind her, facing citations that included failure to comply with a police officer. She worried about steep fines, even jail time, on charges she felt were baseless. But the hearing brought relief.

articles.headline: Donald Trump and the G.O.P. Debate: Policy Is Not His Point
articles.snippet: He may be the first post-policy candidate, building on grass-roots anger over the ineffectiveness and rehearsed talking points of other politicians.
articles.abstract: He may be the first post-policy candidate, building on grass-roots anger over the ineffectiveness and rehearsed talking points of other politicians.
articles.lead_paragraph: He announced a “foolproof” plan to destroy the Islamic State, but said, “I’m not going to tell you what it is tonight.”

articles.headline: ‘Right to Be Forgotten’ Online Could Spread
articles.snippet: Some countries’ demands for the erasure of search engine results on privacy grounds could soon affect even information available in the United States.
articles.abstract: Some countries’ demands for the erasure of search engine results on privacy grounds could soon affect even information available in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than a year ago, in a decision that stunned many American Internet companies, Europe’s highest court ruled that search engines were required to grant an unusual right — the “right to be forgotten.” Privacy advocates cheered the decision by the European Court of Justice, which seemed to offer citizens some recourse to what had become a growing menace of modern life: The Internet never forgets, and, in its robotic zeal to collect and organize every scrap of data about everyone, it was beginning to wreak havoc on personal privacy.

articles.headline: Turkey’s Push Into War Is Seen as Erdogan’s Political Strategy
articles.snippet: Analysts say that by resuming military operations against the Kurds, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is setting the stage for snap elections so his party can regain control of Parliament.
articles.abstract: Analysts say that by resuming military operations against the Kurds, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is setting the stage for snap elections so his party can regain control of Parliament.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Confronted with widespread protests two summers ago, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan ordered a harsh police crackdown and tarnished the demonstrators as traitors and spies. Faced with a corruption inquiry focused on his inner circle, he responded by purging the police and judiciary.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Ceylan Yeginsu
